title: SmileDirectClub Will Begin Trading Today at $23, Above the IPO Range It Had Set
text:
Text size

SmileDirectClub , which sells see-through orthodontic braces, begins trading on the Nasdaq this morning after pricing its initial public offering at $23 on Wednesday.

That’s a dollar above the expected range the company set on Sept. 3, when SmileDirectClub said it would offer its stock at between $19 and $22 a share.

The company, which reported a $432 million in revenues in 2018, has more than 300 retail stores. It is offering 58 million shares in the IPO, which would raise $135 million. The company is also offering underwriters a 30-day option to buy an additional 8.8 million shares.

The back story. Founded in 2014, SmileDirectClub sells direct-to-consumer teeth-straightening treatments. The product has faced criticism from orthodontists, as the company’s model cuts out visits to the dentist’s office. It is one of a handful of direct-to-consumer invisible-aligner companies seeking to dominate the growing market.

Editor's Choice

What’s new. When it begins trading, SmileDirect Club will join competitor Align Technology (ticker: ALGN), a pioneer in the invisible-aligner market, which went public in 2001. The company’s patents began expiring in 2017, clearing the way for a wave of competitors. Unlike Align, which sells its Invisalign product through orthodontist’s offices, SmileDirect and other private companies like Candid Co. employ a direct-to-consumer model.

Shares of Align technology are down 52.6% over the past 12 months. The stock peaked at $391 in July 2018, but has fallen sharply since then.

SmileDirectClub clients visit the company’s retail stores to be fitted with their aligners, or can use a mail-in kit. A SmileDirectClub doctor approves the treatment plan remotely, and prescribes the aligners.

SmileDirect says it is poised to benefit from a growing awareness of “aesthetic image” among consumers. “The proliferation of social media emphasizes online identity and, as a result, drives consumers to present an image of their best selves,” the company said in a September filing. “Within the next 12 months, more than one in three adults in the U.S. are considering at least one cosmetic treatment, with cosmetic dentistry (including teeth alignment, whitening, and veneers) topping the list of nonsurgical treatments.”

Looking ahead. Investors will determine today whether the company is worth the $23 sticker price, after company executives ring the Nasdaq opening bell. SmileDirect will trade under the ticker SDC.
